name: bass-guitar
definition: An electrically amplified musical instrument having four or more heavy strings, held like a guitar and usually played by plucking or striking the strings with the hand.
description:
The bass guitar is a stringed instrument played primarily with the fingers or thumb, by plucking, slapping, popping, strumming, tapping, thumping, or picking with a plectrum.

The bass guitar is similar in appearance and construction to an electric guitar, but with a longer neck and scale length.

Bass guitars are normally made out of wood. They have a few main pieces such as a body, neck, fingerboard, frets, and four to six strings.

At the bottom of the body is an assembly called the bridge, a large metal assembly into which one end of the strings are fitted.

Popular music bands and rock groups use the bass guitar as a member of the rhythm section, which provides the chord sequence or progression and sets out the beat for the song.

The bass guitar is used to play low musical sounds called 'bass lines' in many styles of music such as rock, pop, country, jazz fusion and many more.

facts.name: Frets are placed in the Western tonal scale
facts.value: Frets are placed at specific locations along the fretboard, with each fret representing one half step in the Western tonal scale.

facts.name: Fender model created in 1950s
facts.value: Leo Fender developed a bass guitar in the 1950s using the ideas developed by Tutmarc. Instrument was named 'Fender Precision Bass'.

facts.name: Was invented in the 1930s
facts.value: The bass guitar was first made in the 1930s by inventor Paul Tutmarc from Seattle, Washington. However, very few musicians were interested in the instrument till 1950s.

facts.name: Bridge has adjustments for strings height
facts.value: The bridge often has adjustments that allow the height of the strings to be changed.

facts.name: Basses with two magnetic pickups
facts.value: Basses that have two pickups  - generally referred to as bridge and neck pickups, often have a switch that enables the player to select neck-only, bridge-only, or a blended signal.

facts.name: Tuners for strings tuning
facts.value: At the other end of the fretboard from the body sits the headstock, which generally holds the tuners that permit the player to adjust the tuning of the strings.

facts.name: Replaced the double bass
facts.value: Since the 1960s, the bass guitar has largely replaced the double bass in jazz, blues, folk, early rock music and bluegrass. The problem was that the double bass was big.

facts.name: Fender design is still popular
facts.value: The bass guitar developed by Leo Fender became very popular. Many bass guitars are still designed to look like his Fender Precision Bass.

facts.name: Tuned the same as the double bass
facts.value: The four-string bass is usually tuned the same as the double bass, which corresponds to pitches one octave lower than the four lowest-pitched strings of a guitar.

facts.name: Magnetic devices for strings vibrations
facts.value: The pickups are magnetic devices that sit below the strings. As the strings vibrate, an electrical signal is produced which is routed via an instrument cable to an amplifier.
